name: Medtronic
title: Medtronic Rebrands Diabetes Business as MiniMed - HIT Consultant
description:
What You Should Know: – Medtronic announced that its planned New Diabetes Company will be named MiniMed.
The name honors the company’s roots, reflecting its original name prior to its acquisition by Medtronic in 2001 and its deep, 40-year history of transforming diabetes care worldwide.
The announcement marks a significant step in the intended separation of Medtronic’s Diabetes business into a new, independent entity.
Simplify Life with Diabetes The new MiniMed’s mission is to make diabetes more predictable so that everyone can embrace life to the fullest.
“Our journey began in 1983, when visionary entrepreneur Alfred E. Mann founded MiniMed and revolutionized diabetes care with many first-of-its-kind innovations,” said Que Dallara, current EVP and President of Medtronic Diabetes and Chief Executive Officer designate of MiniMed.
text:
What You Should Know:

– Medtronic announced that its planned New Diabetes Company will be named MiniMed. The name honors the company’s roots, reflecting its original name prior to its acquisition by Medtronic in 2001 and its deep, 40-year history of transforming diabetes care worldwide.

The announcement marks a significant step in the intended separation of Medtronic’s Diabetes business into a new, independent entity.

Simplify Life with Diabetes

The new MiniMed’s mission is to make diabetes more predictable so that everyone can embrace life to the fullest. The company aims to address the constant mental and physical demands required to keep glucose levels in a healthy range, developing technology that helps push the daily burden of diabetes management into the background.

Based in Northridge, California, the Diabetes business consists of a passionate team of more than 8,000 employees. Medtronic is targeting the completion of the planned separation within 18 months of its initial announcement, subject to customary conditions and legal requirements.

“Our journey began in 1983, when visionary entrepreneur Alfred E. Mann founded MiniMed and revolutionized diabetes care with many first-of-its-kind innovations,” said Que Dallara, current EVP and President of Medtronic Diabetes and Chief Executive Officer designate of MiniMed. “We’re thrilled to honor this rich 40-year legacy with a name that carries deep meaning and trust. As we step forward into this new and exciting chapter, we’ll focus relentlessly on fulfilling our Mission.”

name: Michelin
title: Michelin scraps VMware containers for open-source Kubernetes platform | CIO Dive
description:
As customers grappled with the prospect of steep cost increases for operationally critical technologies, a small group of Michelin engineers sensed a transformation opportunity.
“It was a good time to start checking for an open-source project to replace this vendor solution,” Arnaud Pons, platform architect at Michelin, told CIO Dive.
The VMware acquisition was a fork in the road for Michelin’s platform engineering team, which had been running hundreds of applications in the vendor's Tanzu Kubernetes Grid system for several years.
Michelin joined the CNCF in April, a few months after completing the migration to an in-house platform dubbed Michelin Kubernetes services, or MKS, by the engineering team.
The team ran its containers on Azure public cloud but opted against Microsoft’s Kubernetes platform and didn’t turn to a third-party service until it chose Tanzu in 2021.
text:
When Broadcom purchased VMware, IT shops took notice.

The $61 billion deal, finalized in November 2023, signaled a seismic shift in the virtualization software vendor’s expansive and nearly ubiquitous enterprise portfolio, which Broadcom rapidly packaged into just a few subscription service bundles.

As customers grappled with the prospect of steep cost increases for operationally critical technologies, a small group of Michelin engineers sensed a transformation opportunity.

“It was a good time to start checking for an open-source project to replace this vendor solution,” Arnaud Pons, platform architect at Michelin, told CIO Dive.

Digital transformation is rarely a linear process. Modernization journeys often take unexpected turns as enterprises navigate cloud costs, vendor relationships and organization changes.

The VMware acquisition was a fork in the road for Michelin’s platform engineering team, which had been running hundreds of applications in the vendor's Tanzu Kubernetes Grid system for several years. Michelin could either channel its energies into adapting to revamped container services or pivot its own, internally driven strategy.

It wasn’t a difficult decision from an engineering perspective, according to Gabriel Quennesson, Michelin’s container as a service tech lead.

“At the end of the day, we realized that everything that we needed to do was readily available, and possible with open source tools,” Quennesson said in a Thursday case study published by the Cloud Native Computing Foundation.

Michelin joined the CNCF in April, a few months after completing the migration to an in-house platform dubbed Michelin Kubernetes services, or MKS, by the engineering team. The entire process took roughly six months, Quennesson told CIO Dive.

“By having the knowledge of working on the technology for a couple of years, we were able to move rather quickly out of Tanzu — maybe quicker than moving to another vendor solution — because we could identify a migration path that neither VMware nor other vendors could provide us,” said Quennesson.

A team of 11 engineers, including Quennesson and Pons, now manages nearly 450 containerized software applications deployed across 42 locations supporting critical functions, such as ordering and logistics.

“While some of the manpower goes to simply ‘keeping the lights on,’ by ensuring the best platform availability and supportability, the move to open source allows us to start looking at the future and to what features had most value for our end users,” Quennesson said in a March blog post detailing Michelin’s Kubernetes journey.

Pros and cons

From a developer perspective, the case for open source is a relatively easy one: Talented engineers want to build technologies that solve difficult problems. Quennesson and Pons had to make a business argument in favor of migration, too.

After Michelin crunched the numbers, the company determined it could cut its yearly container costs by 44% by building an open-source platform. The open-source shift also lifted the spirits of its engineering team.

“I measure morale first,” Pons said. “It's really better to build a solution to a problem instead of just creating tickets and waiting months for someone at the vendor to call you with a solution that is not a very good one, anyway.”

The business equation was fairly straightforward, as well, according to Quennesson.

“We were more interested in the quality of the solution than the cost, but it’s basic math,” he said. “You are saving the subscription cost, which created a significant cost reduction, and your infrastructure costs are about the same.”

Michelin’s Kubernetes journey began in 2018, when the company first implemented containers using Kubespray to avoid vendor lock-in, Quennesson said in the March blog. The team ran its containers on Azure public cloud but opted against Microsoft’s Kubernetes platform and didn’t turn to a third-party service until it chose Tanzu in 2021.

While Tanzu enabled Michelin to build out and scale its containers both in the cloud and on-premises, the transition wasn’t seamless or without frustrations.

“The Kubernetes ecosystem is large and feature rich,” Quennesson said. “You have to pick and choose what you want and need, so one of the reasons to use a vendor is that this job is done for you.”

VMware’s decisions didn’t always align with Michelin’s needs, according to Quennesson. Relinquishing control to an outside vendor put engineers in an uncomfortably passive role, which created a less inviting atmosphere for developers at a time when tech talent is scarce.

“Skilled engineers were parked in a passive role of opening tickets and interacting with the support teams when they could and most of the time had found out what the issue was and how to fix it,” Quennesson said in the blog post.

Without a vendor to fall back on, the engineering team now has full responsibility for keeping the system up and running. But the tradeoff has been worth it, according to Quennesson.

“It’s created a virtuous circle,” he said. “If you adhere to open source principles and do cool stuff, you attract talent and you make it much easier to retain talent.”

name: Publicis Groupe
title: MARKETING EDGE Summit: Awopetu unveils strategic edge of data-driven storytelling
description:
This powerful message echoed through the MARKETING EDGE 2025 Q2 Virtual Summit held on Friday, June 12, via Zoom.
Baba Awopetu, Consultant, Strategy and Marketing at Stragmar, delivered a keynote address that championed data-driven storytelling as the essential skill for future market leaders.
He reminded attendees that in marketing and sales, data isn’t just a resource; it’s a compass for long-term success.
As an experienced marketing professional, Awopetu described data-driven storytelling as a core business capability.
Themed “Navigating the Future of Sales and Marketing: The Need for Data-Driven Storytelling,” the event featured top professionals who explained why combining storytelling with data is now essential in marketing.
text:
The future of sales and marketing belongs to those who can fuse the precision of data with the emotional pull of compelling narratives.

This powerful message echoed through the MARKETING EDGE 2025 Q2 Virtual Summit held on Friday, June 12, via Zoom.

Baba Awopetu, Consultant, Strategy and Marketing at Stragmar, delivered a keynote address that championed data-driven storytelling as the essential skill for future market leaders.

He emphasised that data-driven storytelling drives deeper customer connections, faster innovation, and stronger market performance.

He reminded attendees that in marketing and sales, data isn’t just a resource; it’s a compass for long-term success.

As an experienced marketing professional, Awopetu described data-driven storytelling as a core business capability.

“Data-driven storytelling is no longer optional; it’s the critical capability that distinguishes market leaders from followers,” he said.

He outlined how data brings clarity in uncertain times, detects unspoken customer needs, enables personalisation, and gives companies an edge.

Read Also: A Nation Reimagined: Nigeria is our communication project

Awopetu stated that companies using data-driven methods achieve 20 per cent higher ROI.

He warned that today’s consumers reject generic messages and expect personalised communication that speaks to their needs.

“Without data, marketing is guesswork, expensive guesswork,” he said.

To show how data shapes strategy, Awopetu shared a study involving 18,000 doctors.

Researchers asked them when they would adopt a new product, from immediate use to waiting until it became standard.

Although 25 per cent claimed to be innovators, only 2.5 per cent truly were.

This revealed the danger of relying on assumptions over objective data.

He noted that innovation adoption depends on context, not just personality.

Researchers cross-referenced preferences with real prescription behaviour, confirming the study’s accuracy in predicting adoption.

He stressed the importance of targeting the right segments early.

He said early adopters provide the fastest path to market share.

“The secret to our success is going to be dependent on us working our way from the innovators and early adopters across over the lifecycle of the product.”

He shared a cautionary tale of a company that focused on late adopters and missed early momentum.

“Because they lacked the data and the insight, they operated based on what they could see.”

Also Watch Marketing Edge ONTV

The oversight weakened product performance and proved why data must guide decisions.

Looking ahead, Awopetu identified key trends in data-driven storytelling.

These include AI-powered narratives, hyper-personalised campaigns, ethical storytelling, and interactive tools.

He wrapped up his session with five key lessons: data turns guesswork into truth; it brings clarity in uncertain times; it detects needs before they are voiced; customers demand personalisation; and data-driven strategies drive better business outcomes.

Victor Ojeakhena, Co-Founder of Marketing Analytics Africa Limited, moderated the summit.

Themed “Navigating the Future of Sales and Marketing: The Need for Data-Driven Storytelling,” the event featured top professionals who explained why combining storytelling with data is now essential in marketing.

name: Kraft Heinz
title: How Kellanova is using data to drive snack sales | Crain's Chicago Business
authors: Crain's Chicago Business, Garett Sloane, Ad Age
description:
AI is a growing part of the mix, bringing sophisticated modeling based on brands’ unique data, an edge only they have.
The initiative led to a 30% increase in first-party data from consumers, Kellanova said.
Gartner has studied the most effective digital marketing brands and found a correlation between the best-in-class brands and hiring data specialists.
Cotterill guided Kellanova to adopt a new clean room strategy with data platform LiveRamp over the past two years.
But using its data clean room, Kellanova was able to gain insights that allowed it to target both groups—premium and price-conscious shoppers—more effectively.
text:
Launching a new packaged snack is never a sure thing.

In fact, new foods fail within 18 months about 85% of the time, according to Charisse Hughes, chief growth officer of Chicago-based Kellanova, whose brands include Cheez-It, Pop-Tarts and Pringles.

That’s why when Kellanova introduced a new chip variety last year, Pringles Mingles, the brand did so within a new data framework that helped guide everything from product design to flavor profiles to advertising.

“It has given us more confidence in what we bring to market,” said Hughes, emphasizing how product and marketing work hand in hand with data teams.

Kellanova recently launched a pilot data program that brings in data scientists, engineers and analysts at the start of projects, influencing pricing, packaging, product, marketing and distribution. “It’s helped us get more winners from the concept phase into execution,” Hughes said.

Brands have long studied the success of new product lines. But their ability to shape those products before they ever hit the market has been revolutionized with new data platforms and technology. Companies have new methods for collecting data through marketing that drives direct feedback from consumers, including via social media promotions, QR codes and rewards apps.

They are using that data in new environments, such as clean rooms, where they make predictions and identify core and untapped audiences. AI is a growing part of the mix, bringing sophisticated modeling based on brands’ unique data, an edge only they have.

“Customer data is really being viewed as this critical enterprise asset, whereas it used to be more of a marketing asset,” said Rachel Smith, senior principal analyst at Gartner.

How brands get better control of data

“CMOs have to have influence on data architecture,” said Gurdeep Dhillon, CMO of ContentStack, “and data teams need to understand marketing and content strategy.”

ContentStack works with major brands, including Air France and Costco, to manage customer experiences, from apps to checkout kiosks in stores.

Brands have access to data through multiple marketing touchpoints, including websites, apps and in-store digital displays. “Content is data,” Dhillon said. But marketers need a coherent plan to ingest that data, manage consumer expectations around how it is used, and apply it appropriately in marketing and services, Dhillon said.

Kellanova is trying to use its advanced data mindset throughout the company, not just marketing. Factories are using virtual reality and “digital twins” to test production plans before implementing them.

Kellanova is developing AI agents, which are autonomous intelligent bots, and distributing those throughout the workforce. The data Kellanova collects is deeply rooted in marketing through programs such as Pringles Poptopia, which launched last year with a QR code that linked to games, customizable snacks and special offers. The initiative led to a 30% increase in first-party data from consumers, Kellanova said.

“We are building a really strong pipeline that is more consumer-facing and much more consumer-centric versus what I would say many CPGs have done historically,” Hughes said, “which is sort of to replicate what they see in market.”

Instead of reacting to market trends, Kellanova wants to apply sophisticated data combined with advanced modeling techniques to accurately map the future, Hughes said.

Marketers and data scientists bridge the divide

Kellanova is bringing together data scientists, engineers, agency partners, marketers, e-commerce specialists and other specialists in new ways. “I’ve gone from probably three years ago when I had never spoken to a data scientist, quite honestly, to now, I talk to them every single day. I couldn’t do my job without them,” said Louise Cotterill, Kellanova’s senior director of insights and intelligence.

There can be tension within brands while they institute these comprehensive data regimes, Gartner’s Smith said. For instance, in some cases, marketers have gotten used to having unfettered access to data. But as IT teams seek to implement greater controls, this can cause conflicts with other departments, which must be managed.

“The enterprise side is really thinking about the future and how to reduce silos and get the data more centrally managed,” Smith said.

Gartner has studied the most effective digital marketing brands and found a correlation between the best-in-class brands and hiring data specialists. The top digital marketers were five times more likely to be promoting roles that included data science and machine learning in the description, Smith said.

The marketing organization is key to success when making technological changes. “They are oftentimes the ones making the business case for the data, for the tech,” Smith said. “They have that closer connection to growth and to retention and acquisition goals.”

How brands can get an AI edge

AI and machine learning will unlock the next phase for brands to create “separation” from rivals, Kellanova’s Hughes said.

Consumer packaged goods brands often lack direct links to consumers because products are sold through third-party retailers. Creative marketing helps, though, and brands can use campaigns to open direct lines to audiences to collect data about the identity and habits of their customers, with direct consent. That data can then inform brands’ proprietary models that make their operations more effective.

As Hughes said, every marketer has access to the same public data sets available through third parties such as Circana, which has purchase information, as well as Experian and Nielsen. So “the models are what’s going to become a differentiator,” she said. And brands can gain an advantage by building unique in-house data models, she added.

Kellanova is filtering data through new channels, which is leading to interesting marketing collaborations. Last year, Pringles designed a boot with Crocs that had cylindrical chip pockets. The campaign led to 1.6 billion impressions, and the boots can be found for resale on StockX for about $800. It was a quirky campaign, but it was also a direct-to-consumer pipeline.

Cotterill guided Kellanova to adopt a new clean room strategy with data platform LiveRamp over the past two years. Clean rooms are computing environments in which brands can bring data sets from a variety of sources, including third parties, to get a better picture of their consumers, build target audiences and measure ad campaigns.

Clean rooms are challenging for CPG brands to stand up because of their distance from first-party sales data. But Kellanova was able to build an effective clean room using new modeling techniques—and patience, Cotterill said.

She cited an effort involving Special K in the U.K. (Kellanova controls the brand internationally.) Special K’s ad targeting was missing some loyal consumers in the U.K, while other consumers stopped buying the brand because of price concerns. But using its data clean room, Kellanova was able to gain insights that allowed it to target both groups—premium and price-conscious shoppers—more effectively.

It took time to get the results they wanted, however, and Cotterill had to stand in front of leadership to urge patience, she said. “You have to have a chief growth officer who believes in it,” Cotterill said.

name: Albertsons
title: New Mexico grocery store workers' union set to vote on strike - KOB.com
description:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. — Members of a union supporting workers at the Smith’s and Albertsons grocery stores in New Mexico are set to vote on authorizing a strike.
The United Food and Commercial Workers Union (UFCW) Local 1564 confirmed they filed unfair labor practice charges with the National Labor Relations Board against the two grocery store chains.
UFCW Local 1564 members, representing workers at various Albertsons and Smith’s locations, will take a strike authorization vote next week over “unfair labor practices, collusion, and bad faith bargaining.” The vote will start Monday and run through the week.
UFCW Local 1564 President Greg Frazier released the following statement: “It has become apparent during our contract negotiations with both Albertsons and Smith’s Food and Drug that these companies are not bargaining in good faith.
We have filed charges with the NLRB against both companies and will be taking strike authorization votes next week.
text:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. — Members of a union supporting workers at the Smith’s and Albertsons grocery stores in New Mexico are set to vote on authorizing a strike.

The United Food and Commercial Workers Union (UFCW) Local 1564 confirmed they filed unfair labor practice charges with the National Labor Relations Board against the two grocery store chains.

UFCW Local 1564 members, representing workers at various Albertsons and Smith’s locations, will take a strike authorization vote next week over “unfair labor practices, collusion, and bad faith bargaining.” The vote will start Monday and run through the week.

UFCW Local 1564 President Greg Frazier released the following statement:

“It has become apparent during our contract negotiations with both Albertsons and Smith’s Food and Drug that these companies are not bargaining in good faith. Both have delayed their grievance and arbitration process, failed to provide vital information needed for negotiations, and are working together despite the FTC and a federal court decisively rejecting a merger between Albertsons and Kroger, the parent company of Smith’s, last year.

“Our hard-working members deserve to be able to do their job and serve customers without the looming threat of their contract expiring. We have filed charges with the NLRB against both companies and will be taking strike authorization votes next week. Our members have the opportunity to send a powerful message to both companies that it is time to change course and come to the table ready to negotiate in good faith.”

The contracts with the grocery store were set to expire Sunday but were extended through June 28.

name: Instacart
title: Instacart's SWOT analysis: grocery delivery leader faces ad revenue challenges
description:
Company Overview Instacart, operating under the corporate name Maplebear Inc. (NASDAQ: ), has established itself as a dominant player in the online grocery delivery market.
Market Position and Competition Instacart holds a dominant position in the U.S. online grocery delivery market, with an estimated 70-75% market share among third-party delivery services.
However, the competitive landscape is intensifying, with well-capitalized players like Amazon (NASDAQ: ), Walmart (NYSE: ), DoorDash (NASDAQ: ), and Uber expanding their presence in the grocery delivery space.
Affordability: The company is working on making grocery delivery more cost-effective for consumers by offering low-cost delivery options and collaborating with merchants to reduce prices.
By continuously improving its ad targeting capabilities and expanding its ad inventory, Instacart could drive significant growth in high-margin advertising revenue.
text:
Instacart, the leading online grocery delivery platform in the United States, has been navigating a competitive landscape while striving to maintain its market dominance. As the company continues to evolve its business model and expand its services, investors and analysts are closely watching its performance and future prospects.

Company Overview

Instacart, operating under the corporate name Maplebear Inc. (NASDAQ: ), has established itself as a dominant player in the online grocery delivery market. With a market capitalization of $11.49 billion, the company maintains a "GREAT" financial health rating according to InvestingPro analysis, reflecting its strong market position and operational efficiency. Founded in 2012, the company has built an extensive network of partnerships with over 85,000 stores across 1,500 retail banners, covering more than 85% of the U.S. grocery market. This broad reach has positioned Instacart as a critical intermediary between retailers, consumers, and shoppers in the rapidly growing digital grocery space.

The company’s platform facilitates both delivery and pick-up orders from various retail partners, including major chains like Aldi, Costco (NASDAQ: ), and Kroger (NYSE: ). Recently, Instacart expanded its offerings through a partnership with Uber (NYSE: ) to include restaurant deliveries, further diversifying its service portfolio.

Financial Performance

Instacart’s financial performance has shown resilience in a challenging market environment. In its most recent quarterly report, the company reported Gross Transaction (JO: ) Value (GTV) of $8.3 billion, representing an 11% year-over-year increase. Revenue for the quarter reached $852 million, up 11.5% compared to the same period last year. The company maintains impressive gross profit margins of 75.22% and a healthy current ratio of 3.24, demonstrating strong operational efficiency. Want deeper insights into CART’s financial metrics? InvestingPro offers comprehensive analysis with over 10 additional key insights. The company’s EBITDA stood at $227 million, or 2.7% of GTV, demonstrating its ability to maintain profitability while investing in growth initiatives.

Analysts project that Instacart will continue to deliver high single-digit revenue growth, with estimates for fiscal year 2025 revenue ranging from $3.66 billion to $3.71 billion. EBITDA margins are expected to expand, with projections for fiscal year 2025 EBITDA ranging from $981 million to $1.01 billion.

Market Position and Competition

Instacart holds a dominant position in the U.S. online grocery delivery market, with an estimated 70-75% market share among third-party delivery services. The company’s scale and extensive partnerships give it a significant advantage in both small and large basket grocery orders.

However, the competitive landscape is intensifying, with well-capitalized players like Amazon (NASDAQ: ), Walmart (NYSE: ), DoorDash (NASDAQ: ), and Uber expanding their presence in the grocery delivery space. These competitors often have more flexibility to address affordability challenges and may be better positioned to capture market share growth in price-sensitive segments.

Growth Strategies

To maintain its market leadership and drive growth, Instacart is pursuing several strategic initiatives:

1. Affordability: The company is working on making grocery delivery more cost-effective for consumers by offering low-cost delivery options and collaborating with merchants to reduce prices. This initiative aims to drive GTV growth and compete more effectively with lower-priced alternatives.

2. Product Innovation: Instacart recently introduced Smart Shop, a personalized user experience for members that incorporates dietary preferences and shopping habits. This AI-driven personalization is expected to increase customer stickiness and improve retention rates.

3. Expansion of Services: The partnership with Uber to power advertising for its grocery and retail business in the U.S. represents a significant growth opportunity for Instacart’s advertising platform.

4. Capital Allocation: The company has demonstrated a commitment to shareholder value through share repurchases, having bought back $1.4 billion in shares year-to-date and announcing an additional $250 million share repurchase authorization. InvestingPro data reveals that Instacart holds more cash than debt on its balance sheet, providing financial flexibility for continued strategic investments and shareholder returns.

Advertising Revenue

A key focus for Instacart’s growth strategy is the expansion of its advertising business. The company aims to increase its advertising revenue to 4-5% of GTV in the long term, up from the current level of around 2.9%. This growth is expected to be driven by new ad formats, improved targeting capabilities, and the expansion of Instacart’s retail media network (RMN) inventory.

However, some analysts have expressed concerns about the sustainability of this growth, citing persistent budget pressures in the Consumer Packaged Goods (CPG) industry and increasing competition in the digital advertising space. The company’s ability to navigate these challenges and achieve its advertising revenue targets will be crucial for its long-term profitability and growth.

Bear Case

How might increasing competition impact Instacart’s market share?

Instacart faces significant challenges from well-established players in the e-commerce and delivery space. Companies like Amazon, Walmart, DoorDash, and Uber have greater financial resources and more diversified business models, allowing them to potentially offer more competitive pricing and absorb losses in their grocery delivery segments. This intense competition could lead to market share erosion for Instacart, particularly in price-sensitive customer segments.

Additionally, as these competitors continue to invest in their grocery delivery capabilities and leverage their existing customer bases, Instacart may find it increasingly difficult to maintain its dominant position. The company’s reliance on partnerships with retailers also leaves it vulnerable to disintermediation if these partners decide to develop their own delivery capabilities or exclusive relationships with other platforms.

What challenges does Instacart face in growing its advertising revenue?

While Instacart has set ambitious targets for its advertising business, several factors could impede its growth in this area. The CPG industry, which forms a significant portion of Instacart’s advertising client base, is experiencing budget pressures that may limit the growth of ad spending. This could make it challenging for Instacart to achieve its long-term goal of increasing advertising revenue to 4-5% of GTV.

Moreover, the digital advertising landscape is becoming increasingly competitive, with major tech companies and retailers expanding their own advertising platforms. This competition could lead to downward pressure on ad rates and make it more difficult for Instacart to attract and retain advertisers. The company’s ability to demonstrate superior ROI for advertisers and develop innovative ad products will be crucial in overcoming these challenges.

Bull Case

How can Instacart leverage its scale to improve profitability?

Instacart’s extensive network of retail partnerships and its dominant market position provide significant opportunities for improving profitability. The company’s scale allows it to optimize its operations, including order batching and routing, which can lead to improved efficiency and lower costs per delivery. This operational leverage could translate into higher margins as the business grows.

Furthermore, Instacart’s vast trove of consumer data and shopping insights can be leveraged to enhance its advertising platform, potentially commanding premium rates from advertisers seeking targeted access to consumers at the point of purchase. By continuously improving its ad targeting capabilities and expanding its ad inventory, Instacart could drive significant growth in high-margin advertising revenue.

What opportunities exist for Instacart to expand its services and increase customer retention?

Instacart has several avenues for service expansion and customer retention improvement. The recent introduction of Smart Shop, which offers personalized shopping experiences, demonstrates the company’s ability to innovate and enhance customer value. By continuing to develop AI-driven features and personalized offerings, Instacart can increase customer engagement and loyalty.

The company’s partnership with Uber to include restaurant deliveries opens up new growth opportunities beyond traditional grocery delivery. This diversification could help Instacart capture a larger share of customers’ food-related spending and increase order frequency. Additionally, by expanding its enterprise solutions for retailers, such as white-label delivery services and in-store technology like Caper Carts, Instacart can deepen its relationships with retail partners and create additional revenue streams.

SWOT Analysis

Strengths

Market leader in online grocery delivery with 70-75% market share

Extensive partnerships with over 85,000 stores across 1,500 retail banners

Strong unit economics and improving EBITDA margins

Robust data analytics capabilities for personalized shopping experiences

Weaknesses

Reliance on advertising revenue for profitability

Higher prices compared to some competitors, potentially limiting growth in price-sensitive segments

Dependence on retail partnerships, which could be at risk if partners develop their own delivery capabilities

Opportunities

Expansion of advertising platform to capture a larger share of CPG marketing budgets

Growth in the overall online grocery market, projected at a 12% three-year CAGR

Diversification of services, including restaurant delivery and enterprise solutions for retailers

Development of AI-driven features to enhance customer experience and retention

Threats

Increasing competition from well-funded players like Amazon, Walmart, DoorDash, and Uber

Potential slowdown in CPG advertising spend due to budget pressures

Risk of disintermediation by retail partners

Macroeconomic factors affecting consumer spending on groceries and delivery services

Analysts Targets

JMP Securities: $55 (June 12, 2025)

Citizens Bank: $55 (June 12, 2025)

Jefferies: $50 (May 27, 2025)

Loop Capital Markets: $58 (May 19, 2025)

Barclays (LON: ): $61 (May 2, 2025)

Seaport Research Partners: $62 (February 12, 2025)

BTIG: $58 (January 14, 2025)

Needham: $56 (January 13, 2025)

Wells Fargo (NYSE: ) Securities: $47 (January 10, 2025)

Deutsche Bank (ETR: ): $37 (December 3, 2024)

JMP Securities: $51 (November 25, 2024)

JMP Securities: $51 (November 13, 2024)

Barclays: $56 (November 13, 2024)

This analysis is based on information available up to June 13, 2025, and reflects the market conditions and analyst opinions as of that date. name: J&J
title: J&J ties early-stage lymphoma CAR-T to 100% response rate in 10 patients - Fierce Biotech
description:
Of the 10 patients who had received one line of prior treatment, an objective response rate (ORR) of 100% was recorded, with all signs of cancer were undetectable for eight of the patients, J&J announced in a June 13 release.
J&J did not mention dose-limiting toxicities in the release.
J&J presented the data at the 2025 European Hematology Association conference in Milan, Italy.
JNJ-4496 came to J&J through a 2023 collaboration and licensing agreement with Chinese-American biotech AbelZeta (formerly Cellular Biomedicine Group).
While the pharma’s competitors, like Novartis, Gilead and AstraZeneca were pushing forward in the area at the time, J&J chose to hang back until the right opportunity came along.
text:
Johnson and Johnson is providing a first look at clinical data for its dual-targeting blood cancer CAR-T program.

In a phase 1b trial of patients with relapsed or refractory large B-cell lymphoma, 22 patients who received the recommended phase 2 dose of the CAR-T were included in the efficacy data with a median follow-up of 4 months. Of the 10 patients who had received one line of prior treatment, an objective response rate (ORR) of 100% was recorded, with all signs of cancer were undetectable for eight of the patients, J&J announced in a June 13 release.

For 12 patients who had received two or more previous therapies, the ORR was 92% and the complete response rate was 75%, the New Jersey company said.

In the trial’s 25-patient safety arm, 84% had grade 3 or 4 treatment-related adverse events, with 28% of patients experiencing serious side effects.

Within the cohort, there were no cases of grade 3 or 4 cytokine release syndrome, the healthcare giant said. One patient experienced grade 1 immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome (ICANS), while another patient with central nervous system lymphoma experienced grade 3 ICANS.

The phase 1b trial’s primary endpoints are the occurrence of adverse events, including dose-limiting toxicities, and the determination of the recommended phase 2 dose, which J&J said in the release was 75 million CAR T-cells. J&J did not mention dose-limiting toxicities in the release.

J&J presented the data at the 2025 European Hematology Association conference in Milan, Italy. A global, open-label component of the phase 1b study is still ongoing.

The autologous CAR-T targets both CD19 and CD20, cell surface proteins commonly expressed by cancerous B cells.

“Only about 40% of patients have long-term remissions with currently available single-antigen-targeting CD19 CAR T therapies," Krish Patel, M.D., the director of lymphoma research at Nashville-based Sarah Cannon Research Institute and principal investigator of the study, said in the release. "The data presented today show encouraging clinical activity and promising safety, and represent a step forward in delivering a potential new treatment option to patients living with the most common type of aggressive lymphoma."

JNJ-4496 came to J&J through a 2023 collaboration and licensing agreement with Chinese-American biotech AbelZeta (formerly Cellular Biomedicine Group). Through that deal, J&J’s pharma unit Janssen paid $245 million upfront for the ex-China rights to JNJ-4496 (called C-CAR039 in China) and another CD20-targeting CAR T called C-CAR066.

The AbelZeta deal marked J&J’s return to the CAR-T field after the 2022 approval of Legend Biotech-partnered Carvykti. While the pharma’s competitors, like Novartis, Gilead and AstraZeneca were pushing forward in the area at the time, J&J chose to hang back until the right opportunity came along.

name: Instacart
title: Costco Offers Two New Member Perks, But Only for Some Customers - Cheapism
description:
Costco members love everything about the store, from the massive key lime pies to the $1.50 hot dog combos in the food court.
There are two new perks of having a Costco membership, according to USA Today.
In order to use it, you’ll have to place an order of $150 or more through sameday.costco.com or Costco via Instacart.
Only Costco executive members will get these new perks.
Don’t head to a Costco at 9 a.m. just yet, executive members, because the new perks don’t go into effect until June 30, 2025.
text:
Costco members love everything about the store, from the massive key lime pies to the $1.50 hot dog combos in the food court. And for some members, things are going to get a little better thanks to a couple new perks of membership to the warehouse club. Not every member will get them, though. Here’s what’s new, and who qualifies.

There are two new perks of having a Costco membership, according to USA Today. The first is extended shopping hours, where certain members can get into the store early — and probably have shorter lines and fewer people clogging up the aisles.

The second new perk is even better. Some members will get a monthly $10 credit for same-day delivery orders. So if you shop at Costco regularly and have your order delivered, that may be a pretty great benefit.

The early shopping hours for those that qualify for this perk will be 9 a.m. to 10 a.m. Sunday through Friday, and 9:30 a.m. to 10 a.m. on Sundays. Normally, Costco opens at 10 a.m. Sunday through Friday, and 9:30 a.m. on Saturday.

Costco also announced that it will be open until 7 p.m. on Saturdays for all customers. Previously, it closed at 6 p.m. on Saturdays.

Some Costco members will get a monthly $10 credit for same day delivery orders. In order to use it, you’ll have to place an order of $150 or more through sameday.costco.com or Costco via Instacart. According to a press release, the credit will be automatically applied to qualifying orders, and can be used once per month.

Of course there’s a catch. Only Costco executive members will get these new perks. That’s the highest level of membership, which means it’s more expensive than gold star membership, the lower tier. An executive membership currently costs $130 per year, but if you plan to use the $10 same day order credit each month, it’ll almost pay for itself over the course of a year.

Don’t head to a Costco at 9 a.m. just yet, executive members, because the new perks don’t go into effect until June 30, 2025.

For more Costco news, sign up for our free newsletters.

name: Albertsons
title: SoCal grocery workers prepare to strike alleging unfair labor practices - ABC7
description:
Thousands of grocery store employees represented by the United Food and Commercial Workers union are preparing for a potential strike.
The move follows allegations of unfair labor practices by major chains, including Ralphs, Vons, and Albertsons.
"This authorization is an unfair labor practice strike authorization, which is a little different than an economic strike," said Kathy Finn, president of UFCW Local 770.
At a union workshop in Los Angeles, members created picket signs and coordinated strike teams, getting ready in case negotiations break down.
"Ralphs is cutting back, I know because they force us into self-checkout," said Marc Spitz, also from Riverside.
text:
LOS ANGELES (KABC) -- Just when grocery prices seemed to be leveling off, Southern California shoppers may soon face another disruption -- this time, at the checkout line.

Thousands of grocery store employees represented by the United Food and Commercial Workers union are preparing for a potential strike. The move follows allegations of unfair labor practices by major chains, including Ralphs, Vons, and Albertsons.

"This authorization is an unfair labor practice strike authorization, which is a little different than an economic strike," said Kathy Finn, president of UFCW Local 770. "So it's not just about the bargaining process."

Union leaders claim that the dispute arises from a pattern of illegal activity by the companies, including allegations of worker surveillance, intimidation and retaliation against union members.

"You should be treating us right," said Kristona Carlton, a grocery worker. "We're here every day. We deserve respect and they're not doing that for us."

While no strike date has been set, workers are preparing. At a union workshop in Los Angeles, members created picket signs and coordinated strike teams, getting ready in case negotiations break down.

Shoppers have taken notice.

"I hate crossing picket lines," said Peggy Ninneman, a shopper from Riverside. "And there are very few other stores to go to."

Others pointed to signs of understaffing and increasing reliance on self-checkout lanes.

"Ralphs is cutting back, I know because they force us into self-checkout," said Marc Spitz, also from Riverside. "They're cutting hours, cutting people, making us check out our own stuff."

The union said it is pushing for higher wages, better staffing and stronger workplace protections.

In a statement, Ralphs defended its bargaining approach and said it is committed to reaching an agreement without disruption.

"We remain actively engaged in bargaining with the union because we believe the best outcomes are achieved at the table, not through disruption," a Ralphs spokesperson said. "Our current offer reflects that commitment, including market-leading wage increases for associates over the life of the agreement, and continued investment in industry-leading healthcare and a pension. These are benefits that many non-union competitors do not offer.

We remain committed to good faith bargaining that rewards our hardworking associates and keeps groceries affordable for our customers."

Union officials maintain that it's not just about economics, it's about respect on the job.

"As a shopper, I would tell them: listen to your employees," said Ninneman. "Nothing works without workers."

name: Albertsons
title: Costco will build its 1st standalone gas station in Mission Viejo - Orange County Register
description:
For a retail chain that makes changes in baby steps, a relatively large leap for Costco is coming to Mission Viejo.
The membership-only retailer will build what city officials say is the chain’s largest gas station and its first fuel-only location.
“It will be successful because they are filling a need for more gas stations.” Price matters Costco may not need to attach a beloved food court to this Mission Viejo gas station because bargains on gas are a powerful lure.
Costco is planning a new store in Lake Forest, 10 miles north of the proposed gas station.
Curiously, designs for a gas station at the Lake Forest warehouse were dropped after the Mission Viejo plan was approved.
text:
For a retail chain that makes changes in baby steps, a relatively large leap for Costco is coming to Mission Viejo.

The membership-only retailer will build what city officials say is the chain’s largest gas station and its first fuel-only location.

Yes, there are many Costcos selling fuel under the chain’s Kirkland brand. It’s a popular membership amenity because the prices are often among the lowest in the market.

Costco also sells gas at one of its warehouses just 2 miles down Cabot Road from the planned site at the Mission Viejo Freeway Center at 25732 El Paseo. However, Mission Viejo documents show that Costco’s new location will be a 40-pump facility – gasoline only, with no retail space or convenience store. And yes, it’s just for Costco members.

The station will be constructed at a shopping center off the 5 freeway between La Paz Road and Oso Parkway. It’s a retail spot best known for South County’s lone Krispy Kreme doughnut shop. The plan includes demolishing a shuttered Bed, Bath & Beyond store.

City spokesman Robert Schick says the city approved the overall plans in March, with grading and building permits now being reviewed. Construction is expected to begin in the fall, with a planned spring 2026 opening.

No-brainer?

Now, selling fuel near one of the nation’s busiest freeways may seem like a no-brainer. But a gas-only location is an against-the-grain tactic.

We’d love to hear the “why?” from Costco. Sadly, the merchant doesn’t comment on store development plans.

Let’s consider industry data. Four out of five gas stations nationwide have a store, too. And while two-thirds of a typical gas-food-beverage store’s sales come from fuel, 60% of the profit usually comes from drinks, food, etc.

Gas-only stations buck two trends: the future of gas-powered vehicles and the higher profitability of non-gas sales. Airports are the spot where the gas-only station grew, because limited competition allows higher profits on fuel, says Jeff Lenard, spokesman for NACS, a trade group for gas-station operators.

David Hackett, an energy expert from Stillwater Associates in Irvine and a regular Costco fuel buyer, likes the gas-only idea. He says one reason California pump prices are so high is that the state has twice as many drivers for every gas station compared with the rest of the nation.

“I think Costco sees this new venture as an opportunity to serve their gasoline-buying members in a new way,” he says. “It will be successful because they are filling a need for more gas stations.”

Price matters

Costco may not need to attach a beloved food court to this Mission Viejo gas station because bargains on gas are a powerful lure.

“It gets people happier than just about anything in commerce,” says Lenard of NACS.

Ponder industry research showing 72% of gas buyers say price is the top motivation for where they buy, but that rises to 86% for shoppers of “big box” stores such as Costco.

“There’s a strong emotional caché with gas prices,” Lenard says. “Costco may be looking to tap into it” with the gas-only store.

Costco also seems to view southern Orange County as a laboratory, of sorts. There’s a car wash at the San Juan Capistrano location – 9 miles down the freeway from the planned gas-only location – one of only 15 nationwide offering that service.

And it’s not the only expansion in this area. Costco is planning a new store in Lake Forest, 10 miles north of the proposed gas station. That would be Costco’s 14th Orange County warehouse store, plus its business center in Westminster.

Curiously, designs for a gas station at the Lake Forest warehouse were dropped after the Mission Viejo plan was approved.

name: McDonald’s
title: McDonald's settles Byron Allen's $10 billion lawsuit over commitment to Black-owned media
description:
In This Article: By Jonathan Stempel (Reuters) -McDonald's has settled a $10 billion lawsuit by the media entrepreneur Byron Allen challenging the fast-food chain's alleged refusal to advertise with Black-owned media.
Friday's settlement between McDonald's and two of Allen's companies, Entertainment Studios Networks and the Weather Group, averts a scheduled July 15 trial in Los Angeles federal court.
301.91 - (-0.41%) At close: 4:00:02 PM EDT In a statement, Allen's companies said "we acknowledge McDonald's commitment to investing in Black-owned media properties and increasing access to opportunity.
Allen also said his Allen Media Group represented more than 90% of Black-owned media.
Allen's networks include The Weather Channel, Cars.TV, Comedy.TV, ES.TV, Justice Central, MyDestination.TV, Pets.TV and Recipe.TV.
text:
In This Article:

By Jonathan Stempel

(Reuters) -McDonald's has settled a $10 billion lawsuit by the media entrepreneur Byron Allen challenging the fast-food chain's alleged refusal to advertise with Black-owned media.

Friday's settlement between McDonald's and two of Allen's companies, Entertainment Studios Networks and the Weather Group, averts a scheduled July 15 trial in Los Angeles federal court.

It also resolves Allen's related $100 million lawsuit against McDonald's in Los Angeles Superior Court.

McDonald's said it will buy ads "at market value" from Allen's companies "in a manner that aligns with its advertising strategy and commercial objectives."

Settlement terms are confidential. McDonald's, based in Chicago, denied wrongdoing in agreeing to settle.

301.91

-

(-0.41%)

At close: 4:00:02 PM EDT

In a statement, Allen's companies said "we acknowledge McDonald's commitment to investing in Black-owned media properties and increasing access to opportunity. Our differences are behind us."

Allen had accused McDonald's of "racial stereotyping" by not advertising with Black-owned media, and lying when it pledged in 2021 to boost national ad spending with those media to 5% from 2% by 2024.

He said he relied on that pledge when seeking new business from McDonald's, only to be rebuffed. Allen also said his Allen Media Group represented more than 90% of Black-owned media.

Allen's networks include The Weather Channel, Cars.TV, Comedy.TV, ES.TV, Justice Central, MyDestination.TV, Pets.TV and Recipe.TV.

(Reporting by Jonathan Stempel in New York; Editing by Bill Berkrot)

name: McDonald’s
title: McDonald's Reaches Settlement with Entertainment Studios Network, Expands Ad Partnership
description:
McDonald's settles litigation with ESN without admitting wrongdoing; continues advertising relationship at market rates, eliminating legal uncertainty.
This settlement agreement between McDonald's and Entertainment Studios Network/The Weather Group represents a significant resolution of pending litigation that carries several important implications.
The commercial nature of the settlement – continuing to purchase advertising at market value – indicates McDonald's has avoided potentially costly punitive damages or premium pricing arrangements.
From a risk management perspective, this settlement effectively eliminates litigation uncertainty by securing a dismissal of the lawsuit.
The reference to McDonald's "three-legged stool model" emphasizes the company's focus on maintaining balanced relationships with its business partners.
text:
McDonald's settles litigation with ESN without admitting wrongdoing; continues advertising relationship at market rates, eliminating legal uncertainty.

This settlement agreement between McDonald's and Entertainment Studios Network/The Weather Group represents a significant resolution of pending litigation that carries several important implications. The structure of this settlement follows a classic corporate dispute resolution pattern that benefits McDonald's in several ways:

The agreement specifically states McDonald's is not admitting any wrongdoing – a standard but crucial protective clause that helps shield the company from reputational damage and potential follow-on litigation. While the underlying claims aren't detailed in the announcement, the statements from both parties suggest the dispute likely centered around advertising practices related to Black-owned media.

The commercial nature of the settlement – continuing to purchase advertising at market value – indicates McDonald's has avoided potentially costly punitive damages or premium pricing arrangements. This market-standard pricing provision suggests the resolution likely won't have material negative financial implications beyond normal advertising expenditures.

From a risk management perspective, this settlement effectively eliminates litigation uncertainty by securing a dismissal of the lawsuit. The confidential nature of the specific terms is standard practice and benefits McDonald's by limiting public disclosure of settlement details, which could otherwise influence other potential plaintiffs.

The mutually respectful public statements from both parties signal an amicable resolution that preserves business relationships – a far better outcome than protracted litigation that could have damaged McDonald's brand equity in relation to diversity commitments. The reference to McDonald's "three-legged stool model" emphasizes the company's focus on maintaining balanced relationships with its business partners.

name: McDonald’s
title: McDonald's Reaches Settlement Over Allegations of Racially Discriminatory Ad Spending
description:
By Kelly Cloonan McDonald's said it has reached a settlement with two companies owned by media mogul Byron Allen that accused the fast-food giant of discriminating against Black-owned media companies.
The fast-food restaurant company said Friday it would continue to purchase advertising from Entertainment Studios Network in a manner that aligns with its advertising strategy, and the network would dismiss its lawsuit against McDonald's.
Under the confidential terms of the agreement, McDonald's isn't admitting any wrongdoing, and the ads sold would be priced at market value, the company said.
Entertainment Studios Network and The Weather Group said they are pleased with the resolution of the lawsuit.
Write to Kelly Cloonan at kelly.cloonan@wsj.com (END) Dow Jones Newswires June 13, 2025 14:14 ET (18:14 GMT) Copyright (c) 2025 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
text:
By Kelly Cloonan

McDonald's said it has reached a settlement with two companies owned by media mogul Byron Allen that accused the fast-food giant of discriminating against Black-owned media companies.

The fast-food restaurant company said Friday it would continue to purchase advertising from Entertainment Studios Network in a manner that aligns with its advertising strategy, and the network would dismiss its lawsuit against McDonald's.

Under the confidential terms of the agreement, McDonald's isn't admitting any wrongdoing, and the ads sold would be priced at market value, the company said.

Entertainment Studios Network and The Weather Group had filed a complaint against McDonald's in 2021, seeking $10 billion in damages as they alleged the restaurant chain engaged in a "discriminatory contracting process and refusals to advertise on Plaintiffs' networks on the basis of race."

Entertainment Studios Network and The Weather Group said they are pleased with the resolution of the lawsuit.

"During the course of this litigation, many of our preconceptions have been clarified, and we acknowledge McDonald's commitment to investing in Black-owned media properties and increasing access to opportunity," the companies said.

McDonald's said it is pleased Allen has come to appreciate the company's commitment to inclusion, and that the commercial arrangement is consistent with its other supplier relationships.

Write to Kelly Cloonan at kelly.cloonan@wsj.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

June 13, 2025 14:14 ET (18:14 GMT)

Copyright (c) 2025 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

name: Instacart
title: Instacart's SWOT analysis: grocery delivery leader faces ad revenue challenges
description:
Company Overview Instacart, operating under the corporate name Maplebear Inc. (NASDAQ: ), has established itself as a dominant player in the online grocery delivery market.
Market Position and Competition Instacart holds a dominant position in the U.S. online grocery delivery market, with an estimated 70-75% market share among third-party delivery services.
However, the competitive landscape is intensifying, with well-capitalized players like Amazon (NASDAQ: ), Walmart (NYSE: ), DoorDash (NASDAQ: ), and Uber expanding their presence in the grocery delivery space.
Affordability: The company is working on making grocery delivery more cost-effective for consumers by offering low-cost delivery options and collaborating with merchants to reduce prices.
By continuously improving its ad targeting capabilities and expanding its ad inventory, Instacart could drive significant growth in high-margin advertising revenue.
text:
Instacart, the leading online grocery delivery platform in the United States, has been navigating a competitive landscape while striving to maintain its market dominance. As the company continues to evolve its business model and expand its services, investors and analysts are closely watching its performance and future prospects.

Company Overview

Instacart, operating under the corporate name Maplebear Inc. (NASDAQ: ), has established itself as a dominant player in the online grocery delivery market. With a market capitalization of $11.49 billion, the company maintains a "GREAT" financial health rating according to InvestingPro analysis, reflecting its strong market position and operational efficiency. Founded in 2012, the company has built an extensive network of partnerships with over 85,000 stores across 1,500 retail banners, covering more than 85% of the U.S. grocery market. This broad reach has positioned Instacart as a critical intermediary between retailers, consumers, and shoppers in the rapidly growing digital grocery space.

The company’s platform facilitates both delivery and pick-up orders from various retail partners, including major chains like Aldi, Costco (NASDAQ: ), and Kroger (NYSE: ). Recently, Instacart expanded its offerings through a partnership with Uber (NYSE: ) to include restaurant deliveries, further diversifying its service portfolio.

Financial Performance

Instacart’s financial performance has shown resilience in a challenging market environment. In its most recent quarterly report, the company reported Gross Transaction (JO: ) Value (GTV) of $8.3 billion, representing an 11% year-over-year increase. Revenue for the quarter reached $852 million, up 11.5% compared to the same period last year. The company maintains impressive gross profit margins of 75.22% and a healthy current ratio of 3.24, demonstrating strong operational efficiency. Want deeper insights into CART’s financial metrics? InvestingPro offers comprehensive analysis with over 10 additional key insights. The company’s EBITDA stood at $227 million, or 2.7% of GTV, demonstrating its ability to maintain profitability while investing in growth initiatives.

Analysts project that Instacart will continue to deliver high single-digit revenue growth, with estimates for fiscal year 2025 revenue ranging from $3.66 billion to $3.71 billion. EBITDA margins are expected to expand, with projections for fiscal year 2025 EBITDA ranging from $981 million to $1.01 billion.

Market Position and Competition

Instacart holds a dominant position in the U.S. online grocery delivery market, with an estimated 70-75% market share among third-party delivery services. The company’s scale and extensive partnerships give it a significant advantage in both small and large basket grocery orders.

However, the competitive landscape is intensifying, with well-capitalized players like Amazon (NASDAQ: ), Walmart (NYSE: ), DoorDash (NASDAQ: ), and Uber expanding their presence in the grocery delivery space. These competitors often have more flexibility to address affordability challenges and may be better positioned to capture market share growth in price-sensitive segments.

Growth Strategies

To maintain its market leadership and drive growth, Instacart is pursuing several strategic initiatives:

1. Affordability: The company is working on making grocery delivery more cost-effective for consumers by offering low-cost delivery options and collaborating with merchants to reduce prices. This initiative aims to drive GTV growth and compete more effectively with lower-priced alternatives.

2. Product Innovation: Instacart recently introduced Smart Shop, a personalized user experience for members that incorporates dietary preferences and shopping habits. This AI-driven personalization is expected to increase customer stickiness and improve retention rates.

3. Expansion of Services: The partnership with Uber to power advertising for its grocery and retail business in the U.S. represents a significant growth opportunity for Instacart’s advertising platform.

4. Capital Allocation: The company has demonstrated a commitment to shareholder value through share repurchases, having bought back $1.4 billion in shares year-to-date and announcing an additional $250 million share repurchase authorization. InvestingPro data reveals that Instacart holds more cash than debt on its balance sheet, providing financial flexibility for continued strategic investments and shareholder returns.

Advertising Revenue

A key focus for Instacart’s growth strategy is the expansion of its advertising business. The company aims to increase its advertising revenue to 4-5% of GTV in the long term, up from the current level of around 2.9%. This growth is expected to be driven by new ad formats, improved targeting capabilities, and the expansion of Instacart’s retail media network (RMN) inventory.

However, some analysts have expressed concerns about the sustainability of this growth, citing persistent budget pressures in the Consumer Packaged Goods (CPG) industry and increasing competition in the digital advertising space. The company’s ability to navigate these challenges and achieve its advertising revenue targets will be crucial for its long-term profitability and growth.

Bear Case

How might increasing competition impact Instacart’s market share?

Instacart faces significant challenges from well-established players in the e-commerce and delivery space. Companies like Amazon, Walmart, DoorDash, and Uber have greater financial resources and more diversified business models, allowing them to potentially offer more competitive pricing and absorb losses in their grocery delivery segments. This intense competition could lead to market share erosion for Instacart, particularly in price-sensitive customer segments.

Additionally, as these competitors continue to invest in their grocery delivery capabilities and leverage their existing customer bases, Instacart may find it increasingly difficult to maintain its dominant position. The company’s reliance on partnerships with retailers also leaves it vulnerable to disintermediation if these partners decide to develop their own delivery capabilities or exclusive relationships with other platforms.

What challenges does Instacart face in growing its advertising revenue?

While Instacart has set ambitious targets for its advertising business, several factors could impede its growth in this area. The CPG industry, which forms a significant portion of Instacart’s advertising client base, is experiencing budget pressures that may limit the growth of ad spending. This could make it challenging for Instacart to achieve its long-term goal of increasing advertising revenue to 4-5% of GTV.

Moreover, the digital advertising landscape is becoming increasingly competitive, with major tech companies and retailers expanding their own advertising platforms. This competition could lead to downward pressure on ad rates and make it more difficult for Instacart to attract and retain advertisers. The company’s ability to demonstrate superior ROI for advertisers and develop innovative ad products will be crucial in overcoming these challenges.

Bull Case

How can Instacart leverage its scale to improve profitability?

Instacart’s extensive network of retail partnerships and its dominant market position provide significant opportunities for improving profitability. The company’s scale allows it to optimize its operations, including order batching and routing, which can lead to improved efficiency and lower costs per delivery. This operational leverage could translate into higher margins as the business grows.

Furthermore, Instacart’s vast trove of consumer data and shopping insights can be leveraged to enhance its advertising platform, potentially commanding premium rates from advertisers seeking targeted access to consumers at the point of purchase. By continuously improving its ad targeting capabilities and expanding its ad inventory, Instacart could drive significant growth in high-margin advertising revenue.

What opportunities exist for Instacart to expand its services and increase customer retention?

Instacart has several avenues for service expansion and customer retention improvement. The recent introduction of Smart Shop, which offers personalized shopping experiences, demonstrates the company’s ability to innovate and enhance customer value. By continuing to develop AI-driven features and personalized offerings, Instacart can increase customer engagement and loyalty.

The company’s partnership with Uber to include restaurant deliveries opens up new growth opportunities beyond traditional grocery delivery. This diversification could help Instacart capture a larger share of customers’ food-related spending and increase order frequency. Additionally, by expanding its enterprise solutions for retailers, such as white-label delivery services and in-store technology like Caper Carts, Instacart can deepen its relationships with retail partners and create additional revenue streams.

SWOT Analysis

Strengths

Market leader in online grocery delivery with 70-75% market share

Extensive partnerships with over 85,000 stores across 1,500 retail banners

Strong unit economics and improving EBITDA margins

Robust data analytics capabilities for personalized shopping experiences

Weaknesses

Reliance on advertising revenue for profitability

Higher prices compared to some competitors, potentially limiting growth in price-sensitive segments

Dependence on retail partnerships, which could be at risk if partners develop their own delivery capabilities

Opportunities

Expansion of advertising platform to capture a larger share of CPG marketing budgets

Growth in the overall online grocery market, projected at a 12% three-year CAGR

Diversification of services, including restaurant delivery and enterprise solutions for retailers

Development of AI-driven features to enhance customer experience and retention

Threats

Increasing competition from well-funded players like Amazon, Walmart, DoorDash, and Uber

Potential slowdown in CPG advertising spend due to budget pressures

Risk of disintermediation by retail partners

Macroeconomic factors affecting consumer spending on groceries and delivery services

Analysts Targets

Citizens Bank: $55 (June 12, 2025)

Jefferies: $50 (May 27, 2025)

name: Publicis Groupe
title: Publicis Cannes campaign pits low cost of influencer reach against Super Bowl TV ads
description:
CANNES, FRANCE: Publicis Groupe’s annual Cannes campaign aims to be the most famous lion on the Croisette by proving the power of influencer marketing for a “fraction of the cost” of Super Bowl ads and other traditional media placements.
This year’s Super Bowl reached 127 million viewers, and a 30-second ad placement cost about $8 million.
Detert told Campaign that to get the same reach as the Super Bowl, advertisers can spend anywhere between $450,000 and $2 million.
The campaign demonstrates the cost with a supporting out-of-home campaign stating, “Get Super Bowl reach, for the price of 25 Cannes passes."
“We think that there is a play for not just the big moments like the Super Bowl to amplify, but really having an always-on campaign with creators.
text:
CANNES, FRANCE: Publicis Groupe’s annual Cannes campaign aims to be the most famous lion on the Croisette by proving the power of influencer marketing for a “fraction of the cost” of Super Bowl ads and other traditional media placements.

The “tongue-in-cheek” campaign will begin on Monday, with two wildlife influencers – @shandorlarenty (9.3 million followers on TikTok, 596,000 followers on Instagram) and @Pubity (40 million followers on Instagram, 17 million on TikTok) – sharing a joint post featuring a lion.

Using Publicis’ recent acquisitions of Influential and Captiv8, the campaign will begin engaging other influencers using the platform and its technology to share, talk about and remix the video.

A live “Lion Tracker” at Influential Beach will monitor the lion’s growing audience in real time.

This year’s Super Bowl reached 127 million viewers, and a 30-second ad placement cost about $8 million.

Ryan Detert, Influential’s chief executive, has predicted that the campaign will surpass this within the first 48 hours, using the technology and platforms provided by Influential and Captiv8.

Detert told Campaign that to get the same reach as the Super Bowl, advertisers can spend anywhere between $450,000 and $2 million.

The campaign demonstrates the cost with a supporting out-of-home campaign stating, “Get Super Bowl reach, for the price of 25 Cannes passes." The billboards will be seen in Nice airport and on the Croisette throughout the festival with a QR code that leads to an interactive platform showing what reach can be gained from different amounts of spend.

It compares four Wall Street Journal full-page ads, a Times Square takeover and a 10-second big game spot, showing how much reach the equivalent spend would get via the Influential and Captiv8 platforms with influencer marketing.

Iterations of the campaign show other “Cannes currencies” including “...for the cost of 10 NYC-Nice business class tickets” and “...170 of the 2,400 awards entries," taking a dig at the awards entries that some “flood the system with to rack up metal," the agency said.

Publicis Groupe chief strategy officer Carla Serrano told Campaign that the idea aims to show how much brands are spending in Cannes, but also how cost efficient it could be.

While the campaign is putting the power of influencers in competition with traditional media, Detert argued that the point is to prove it as an “and” as opposed to an “or."

“We think that there is a play for not just the big moments like the Super Bowl to amplify, but really having an always-on campaign with creators. They become your media channel,” he told Campaign.

Serrano added that clients might feel that Cannes is an “indulgence” in a year of economic challenges for businesses. This chimes with group chief executive Arthur Sadoun’s comments calling for a “different approach” to Cannes.

Sadoun said the festival should be providing brands with “immediate” business solutions rather than “AI theory” or “celebrating creativity for its own sake." This campaign intends to provide practical business solutions for brands.

“At Cannes this year, we’re focused on turning AI hype into business upside – with practical, Monday-ready solutions our clients can put to work immediately," he said.

Last year, Publicis’ mocking "taking the BS out of AI" Cannes campaign caused controversy, upsetting its agency rivals. The Paris-based holding company's primary PR network is MSL.

Serrano said this year’s campaign is “less provocative” and intends to be “useful”.

name: Starbucks
title: Starbucks launches own version of viral TikTok trend but with a twist after cutting 13 fan ...
description:
STARBUCKS has launched its own version of a viral TikTok trend with a twist, just after it axed 13 items from its menu.
Starbucks is following the trends these days, and is joining the protein coffee game to prove it.
CEO INNOVATION Brian Niccol has been vocal about the innovative new steps he wants Starbucks to be taking.
In place of the cuts, Starbucks is adding new items to its menu for the summer, including two new bakery items.
A new coffee, dubbed the Starbucks 1971 Roast, is coming to Starbucks spots in the US and Canada this winter.
text:
STARBUCKS has launched its own version of a viral TikTok trend with a twist, just after it axed 13 items from its menu.

The coffee giant is making big moves to get back to its former glory, as the CEO says "it's time for us to lead again".

Starbucks is following the trends these days, and is joining the protein coffee game to prove it.

The company is currently testing out a new cold foam option that adds 15 grams of protein to its drinks, along with an unsweetened protein powder.

The new drink being trialled is a sugar-free vanilla latte with banana foam, which is the thing that contains the protein.

Starbucks is testing out the drink at 5 locations currently, and a potential full launch date has not yet been confirmed.

CEO Brian Niccol is being upfront about where his innovation is leading him, and which direction he is going in.

He said: "It's on trend. It's delicious."

The CEO also told Axios: "I was watching people coming to our stores, they would get three shots of espresso over ice.

"And in some cases, they pull their own protein powder out of their bag, or in other cases, they have a protein drink, like a Fair Life and they'd pour that into their drink.

"I'm like, well, wait a second, we can make this experience better for them.

"The good news is now I think we're right on trend, and we can do it I think arguably better than anybody else."

Other companies, like the coffee chain Dutch Bros, have already jumped on the high-protein train.

It comes as more and more members of Gen Z show an interest in health beverages.

CEO INNOVATION

Brian Niccol has been vocal about the innovative new steps he wants Starbucks to be taking.

Brian Niccol has declared that it is time to "lead in warm, welcoming coffee houses.

"We’re going to lead in innovation. Innovation to our menu."

Earlier this year, he oversaw 30% cuts to both beverages and food in an effort to "clear the noise out both in food and beverage menus."

Niccol later justified himself in an earnings call: "That opens the door for better innovation that will hopefully resonate even more so for our customers.

"We’ve taken steps to refocus the business, our mission and our marketing to better align with our identity as a coffee company."

In place of the cuts, Starbucks is adding new items to its menu for the summer, including two new bakery items.

These include a raspberry croissant filled with jam and a double chocolate cookie topped with flaky sea salt.

The drinks menu is also being updated with new offerings and new twists on familiar favorites.

A new coffee, dubbed the Starbucks 1971 Roast, is coming to Starbucks spots in the US and Canada this winter.

The drink offers a dark roast blend of beans from Sumatra, Colombia and Brazil.

Starbucks is also celebrating the 30th anniversary of its iconic Frappuccino with the Strato Frappuccino.

Strato, which means "layer" in Italian, adds a cloud of cold foam on top of any Frappuccino flavor.
